answers.text: a hardware disk controller with programmable search capabilities

qas.question: Did the CAFS accelerator work as planned?
How are today's database systems run?
Name a company that is still working on the CAFS accellerator?

plausible_answers.text: a hardware disk controller with programmable search capabilities

qas.question: What is no longer used in modern database systems?
What companies still work on the CAFS decelerator?

plausible_answers.text: software systems running on general-purpose hardware

qas.question: What was a failed approach to hardware support for database management?

context: Another approach to hardware support for database management was <b8_0>ICL's CAFS accelerator<b8_0/>, <a0_0><b4_0>a hardware disk controller with programmable search capabilities<b4_0/><a0_0/>. In the long term, these <a1_0>efforts were generally unsuccessful<a1_0/> because specialized database machines could not keep pace with the rapid development and progress of general-purpose computers. Thus most database systems nowadays are <b7_0>software systems running on <a2_0><b5_0>general-purpose hardware<b7_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/>, using general-purpose computer data storage. However this idea is still pursued for certain applications by some companies like <a3_0><b6_0>Netezza and Oracle (Exadata)<b6_0/><a3_0/>.
